excerpt: Grand Roman gateway dating from 180 AD with towers made from heavy stone slabs.
detail_description: Porta Nigra, also known as the Black Gate, is a grand Roman gateway dating back to 180 AD. It is the largest monument of its kind in the north of Italy and serves as a natural starting point for exploring Trier. Despite several renovation projects over the years, its imposing size and unmissable Roman design have been retained. Visitors can walk through it and even go up into it to appreciate the detailed carvings and sheer size.
name: Porta Nigra

excerpt: Romanesque, Gothic & baroque architecture & art meet in this vaulted, fortress-style cathedral.
detail_description: Trier Saint Peter's Cathedral is a stunning blend of Romanesque, Gothic, and baroque architecture. The cathedral features a vaulted, fortress-style design that showcases a mix of artistic styles. Visitors can explore the Market Cross at its center, dating back to 958, and the St Peters Fountain adorned with allegorical figures representing cardinal virtues and playful monkeys. The exterior boasts unique decorations such as Madonnas, gold stars, water features, and oxen.
name: Trier Saint Peter's Cathedral

detail_description: Hauptmarkt, located in Trier, is the central and most stunning square in the city. The Market Cross, dating back to 958, is a prominent feature at its center and holds the title of being Germany's oldest Market Cross. Additionally, visitors can admire the Petrusbrunnen fountain with allegorical representations of justice, steadfastness, temperance, and prudence.
name: Hauptmarkt

excerpt: This bridge over the Moselle River is the oldest in Germany, with pillars dating to the 2nd century.
detail_description: The Roman Bridge in Trier, Germany, is a historic landmark dating back to the 2nd century. It spans the Moselle River and is renowned as the oldest bridge in Germany. While its original pillars date back to ancient times, the arches and roadway were reconstructed in the 18th century. During World War II, it narrowly escaped demolition by the German army. The area surrounding the bridge offers charming riverside restaurants and a youth hostel with efficient German hospitality.
name: Roman Bridge

excerpt: 1600-year-old Roman baths with theater-size hot water bath, underground tunnels & ancient ruins.
detail_description: Kaiserthermen, also known as the Imperial Baths, is a 1600-year-old Roman bath complex located in Trier. Built in the 3rd century by Emperor Constantine, these baths were intended as a gift to the city's inhabitants but were never completed. The remaining walls stand at an impressive 19 meters high and offer visitors a glimpse into the past.
name: Kaiserthermen

excerpt: Guided tours are offered of this 17th-century palace with sculptures & manicured gardens.
detail_description: The Electoral Palace, located in Trier, is a 17th-century palace with guided tours available for visitors. The Aula Palatina, also known as the Basilica of Constantine, was originally a Roman palace basilica and is now used as the oldest Protestant church in Catholic Trier. The palace was once the residence of the Archbishop and Electors of the powerful Electorate of Trier within the Holy Roman Empire.
name: Electoral Palace

excerpt: Exhibits on Marx & the history of Communism, in his birthplace, with letters & personal possessions.
detail_description: Karl Marx House, located in Trier at Bruckenstrasse 10, is a museum dedicated to the life and work of Karl Marx and the history of communism. The museum showcases exhibits featuring letters, personal possessions, and details about Marx's humble origins and life journey. Despite being born in 1818 in this house and spending 17 years here until graduating high school, some visitors may not be particularly familiar with Marx or his ideas.
name: Karl Marx House

excerpt: Striking early Gothic church opening to an airy, multi-arched interior shaped like a rose.
detail_description: The Church of Our Lady in Trier, known as Liebfrauenkirche, is a stunning example of early Gothic architecture and holds the title of Germany's oldest Gothic church. Its interior features an airy design with multiple arches that evoke the image of a rose, reflecting its dedication to the Virgin Mary. When visiting this remarkable site, you’ll find yourself surrounded by other historical treasures such as the Porta Nigra and St.
name: Church of Our Lady in Trier

excerpt: Museum showcasing paintings, sculptures, textiles & furnishings related to city's cultural history.
detail_description: The City Museum Simeonstift Trier, located near the iconic Porta Nigra, offers a diverse collection that spans from medieval artifacts to Renaissance paintings and Coptic textiles. Visitors can explore Egyptian mummy portraits and original stone work while admiring a large model showcasing Trier in 1800. The museum also houses the Toy Museum on Nagelstrasse, featuring an impressive array of German-made toys such as mechanical toys, trains, dolls, tin soldiers, and stuffed animals.
name: City Museum Simeonstift Trier

excerpt: Ornate 12th-century Benedictine church complex housing the tomb of the apostle Matthias.
detail_description: The 12th-century St. Matthias Abbey is a monastery in Trier, Germany that was founded by Saint Matthias the Apostle. The church is popular with Catholic pilgrims and during the days of yore, monks used to live here. The impressive building and its ancient graves are unforgettable sights for anyone visiting Trier.
name: St. Matthias' Abbey

excerpt: This sizable Roman amphitheater utilizes a natural slope of the earth for audience seating.
detail_description: The Trier Amphitheater is a Roman monument from the 2nd century AD which is still in use for public entertainment. It was built on a natural slope of the earth, and during antiquity it hosted animal fights, gladiator battles and executions.
name: Trier Amphitheater

excerpt: Historic remains of a 2nd-century stone Roman bath complex, viewed from an outdoor walkway.
detail_description: Barbara Baths, a 2nd-century Roman bath complex in Trier, was once the second largest of its kind in the Roman Empire, covering an impressive 42,000 square meters. The complex boasted luxurious spa and wellness facilities including heated pools, beauty salons, restaurants, a cultural center and a library. Although only a portion of the original site remains today, visitors can stroll along an outdoor walkway to view mock-ups of the grand baths.
name: Barbara Baths

detail_description: Located in Hauptmarkt, Trier, the Spielzeugmuseum is a delightful toy museum housing around 5,000 antique and contemporary toys. The collection includes miniature trains, dolls, soldiers, Lego sets, and even a 130-year-old dancing bear. Visitors can interact with some of the toys on display. Despite its small size, the museum offers a well-organized layout that is easily navigable. It also features a lift for easy access to all floors.
name: Spielzeugmuseum Trier

excerpt: Trier is a southwestern German city in the Moselle wine region, near the Luxembourg border. Founded by the Romans, it contains several well-preserved Roman structures like the Porta Nigra gate, the ruins of Roman baths, an amphitheater just outside the center and a stone bridge over the Moselle River. The Archaeological Museum displays Roman artifacts. Among Trier’s many Catholic churches is Trier Cathedral.
detail_description: Trier, located in the Moselle wine region near the Luxembourg border, is a city with a rich Roman history. It boasts well-preserved Roman structures such as the Porta Nigra gate, Roman baths ruins, an amphitheater just outside the center, and a stone bridge over the Moselle River. The city also houses the Archaeological Museum which showcases various Roman artifacts. Trier is home to several Catholic churches including Trier Cathedral.
name: Trier

detail_description: Dreikönigenhaus, also known as the House of the Three Magi, is a historic Romanesque and Gothic patrician house located in Trier, Germany. Built in 1230 as a fortified tower for a wealthy family, it stands out with its colorful Moorish design and semi-circular windows. Originally serving as the headquarters of the Teutonic Order in Trier, it is now a popular tourist destination.
name: Dreikönigenhaus

excerpt: Built in the 15th century, this Roman Catholic church is dedicated to St. Gangulphus.
detail_description: The St. Gangolf Church is a Roman Catholic church located in Trier, Germany. It was built in the 15th century and is dedicated to St. Gangulphus. The church's white and yellow façade can be seen from the Porta Nigra and it sits just behind the Hauptmarkt. While it dates back to 958, it was reconstructed in the 13th century with its tower being built in the 14th century.
name: St. Gangolf Kirche

excerpt: Relaxed choice with a summer terrace, offering local wines & a seasonal menu of German standards.
detail_description: Weinstube Kesselstatt is a popular choice in Trier, offering a relaxed atmosphere with a summer terrace where visitors can savor local wines and enjoy a seasonal menu of German classics. Situated across from the cathedral and the Church of Lady, it's an ideal spot to dine on the terrace while sampling top-quality regional wines. The self-service menu features 'Region's Best,' showcasing a delectable array of fish, sausages, and cheese.
name: Weinstube Kesselstatt

excerpt: Elegant, landscaped French-style garden with fountains, sculptures, flower beds & an outdoor cafe.
detail_description: Palastgarten is an elegant, French-style garden featuring fountains, sculptures, and flower beds. The centerpiece of the garden is a pool surrounded by ornate statues and tall hedges. Nearby attractions include the Landesmuseum with Roman artifacts and remnants of Medieval city walls. Adjacent to the Konstantin Basilika is the Kurfurstliches Palais, offering a romantic stroll through formal gardens alongside the gorgeous palace exterior.
name: Palastgarten

excerpt: Robust German dishes, plus coffee & cake, in an eclectic venue with Roman artifacts & a courtyard.
detail_description: Weinstube Zum Domstein is a charming restaurant located between the Main Market Square and the Cathedral in Trier. The venue boasts an eclectic atmosphere with Roman artifacts and a courtyard, making it a perfect spot to unwind after exploring the city. While offering traditional German cuisine during the day, its standout feature is the delectable dishes inspired by ancient local recipes dating back to the first century.
name: Weinstube Zum Domstein

detail_description: St. Peter's Basilica is a must-visit in Trier, Germany. It is believed to have been the throne room for the emperor during Roman times and boasts impressive architecture with double rows of windows that allow natural light to flood in. The basilica holds historical significance and offers visitors the chance to see relics, including the tunic of Jesus Christ, making it a spiritually enriching experience.
name: St. Peter's Basilica

detail_description: In Trier, visitors can explore a variety of attractions, such as the Rheinisches Landesmuseum and the ancient Basilica of St. Matthew. The city also boasts historical landmarks like St. Gangolf church and Mariensaeule, which offers stunning panoramic views of Trier and the Moselle valley. Additionally, tourists can marvel at St.
name: Mariensäule

excerpt: Audio guides are offered in this grand building featuring archeological finds from the Roman Empire.
detail_description: The Rhineland State Museum Trier is a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts and culture seekers alike. Nestled next to the iconic Porta Nigra, this grand museum showcases an impressive collection of archaeological treasures from the Roman Empire. As you wander through its halls, you'll encounter original statues and artistic masterpieces that are often replicated throughout the city, offering a unique glimpse into Trier's rich heritage. While exploring this remarkable museum, don't miss out on other nearby attractions such as St.
name: Rhineland State Museum Trier

detail_description: Hauptmarkt is the main market square in the heart of Nuremberg, Germany. It is a bustling and vibrant area surrounded by beautiful historical buildings and colorful facades. The square is famous for its lively atmosphere, with street performers, local vendors, and tourists all adding to the excitement. Visitors can find a variety of goods at the market, including fresh produce, handmade crafts, and traditional German delicacies.
name: Hauptmarkt

detail_description: Kornmarkt, located in downtown Trier, is a charming square featuring an ornate water fountain and surrounded by shops, outdoor seating areas, and sprawling restaurant terraces. It's a perfect spot to take a break during a day of exploration, especially when the weather is nice. In addition to its cozy atmosphere and lovely cafes where you can enjoy delicious coffee, the square also hosts an ice rink in December.
name: Kornmarkt

excerpt: A menu of diverse potato dishes is offered in an easygoing venue with a seasonal terrace.
detail_description: The rustic yet comfortable Kartoffel Kiste is a great place to enjoy diverse potato dishes all season long. The restaurant has a seasonal terrace where diners can sit and relax. There's also plenty of seating inside, as well as wheelchair access. The menu offers a variety of European inspired dishes made with potatoes. All of the food is vegan, gluten free, and vegetarian friendly.
name: Restaurant Kartoffel Kiste

detail_description: Igeler Säule is a unique sight in Trier, located north of the Alps. It is a monument or grave marker for a wealthy family from the textile industry. Originally brightly painted, it stands out with its unusual colors, providing a glimpse into ancient viewing habits. A replica with the original colors can be seen in the museum in Trier.
name: Igel Column

excerpt: Built in 310 CE by Roman emperor Constantine, the former throne hall is used as a Protestant church.
detail_description: Konstantin-Basilika (Evangelische Kirche zum Erlöser)- Evangelische Kirchengemeinde Trier is a historic site with a rich legacy dating back to 310 CE. Originally built as the throne hall of Roman emperor Constantine, it now serves as a Protestant church. The structure is an architectural marvel, representing one of the largest single-room buildings from Roman times that still stands today.
name: Konstantin-Basilika (Evangelische Kirche zum Erlöser)- Evangelische Kirchengemeinde Trier

detail_description: Nestled in the northern part of Trier, the Basilica of St. Paulinus stands as a testament to both history and artistry. Originally built around AD 400 to honor Saint Paulinus, a revered martyr, this church underwent a stunning Baroque transformation between 1734 and 1753 under the skilled hands of architect Johann Balthasar Neumann. As you approach its vibrant exterior, you might not anticipate the breathtaking beauty that awaits within.
name: Basilica of St. Paulinus, Trier

excerpt: Ruins of a circa-100 CE Roman thermal bath complex, enclosed by a sleek, modern glass cube.
detail_description: Forum Baths is a Roman thermal bath complex dating back to circa 100 CE, now enclosed by a modern glass cube. The site hosts regular events under the glass cube, such as the wine forum in January, offering an opportunity to sample wines and engage with regional winemakers. It also features ruins of other Medieval structures and offers insight into the Roman era. The well-preserved site includes informational videos and facilities like a wardrobe, elevator, and toilets.
name: Thermen Am Viehmarkt - Trier

detail_description: Petrisberg, located on the outskirts of Trier, is home to the charming Petrisberg Viewpoint. This small observation deck offers breathtaking views of the city, Mosel River, and expansive vineyards. After soaking in the stunning scenery, visitors can explore walking paths that meander through the vineyards. For those seeking refreshment, there are terraces near the University campus where one can enjoy a drink while taking in the picturesque surroundings.
name: Petrisberg

excerpt: Restored residential tower built for defensive purposes in the 11th century with a Roman design.
detail_description: Frankenturm Trier is a restored residential tower originally built for defensive purposes in the 11th century, featuring a Roman design. It is one of the must-visit attractions in Trier, Germany. A weekend trip to Trier would be incomplete without exploring this historical gem along with other notable landmarks such as Porta Nigra, Karl Marx statue, Dreikonigenhaus, Church of Lady Trier, Cathedral of St.Peter and more.
name: Frankenturm Trier (Historisches Gebäude)

excerpt: Elegant, landscaped French-style garden with fountains, sculptures, flower beds & an outdoor cafe.
detail_description: Kurfürstliches Palais und Palastgarten is a beautiful and serene park located in the heart of Trier. The well-maintained garden features charming fountains, ducks, and vibrant flowers, making it a picturesque spot for leisurely strolls or relaxation on the numerous benches scattered throughout. Families with children can also enjoy the spacious layout and a playground area. Visitors can savor delicious meals at the adjacent café at reasonable prices.
name: Palastgarten

detail_description: Mariensäule, also known as St. Mary's Column, is a towering Catholic statue situated on a mountain ridge overlooking the city and Mosel River in Trier, Germany. The monument, inaugurated in 1866, offers breathtaking panoramic views of the Roman town of Trier and the surrounding landscape. Accessible via a steep and challenging route or by bus 10, Mariensäule provides excellent photo opportunities and is considered one of the most beautiful viewpoints in the area.
name: Mariensäule

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Trier, Germany's oldest city, Masons Restaurant offers a delightful culinary journey that spans the globe. This unique dining experience allows guests to indulge in an all-you-can-eat format, where they can savor small plates from various international cuisines over two-hour slots. With a menu thoughtfully organized by continent, diners can explore diverse flavors and dishes from different countries. The innovative ordering system via iPads at each table adds a modern twist to the experience.
name: masons Restaurant Trier

excerpt: Quaint, warm restaurant dishing up Mexican staples with Southern Californian flair.
detail_description: Chicano is a charming little restaurant that brings the vibrant flavors of Southern California to Europe, blending authentic Mexican cuisine with a unique Californian twist. This cozy eatery has garnered praise for its delicious dishes and delightful desserts, making it a hidden gem among food enthusiasts. Chef Ariel Morfin, hailing from San Diego, infuses his meals with rich Mexican heritage, ensuring every bite is packed with flavor. The warm atmosphere welcomes guests and even their furry friends!
name: Chicano

detail_description: The wildlife park Wildfreigehege Weißhauswald is a great place to go if you want to see some of the native animals in their natural environment. It's also a great place for people who want to learn about the ecology and history of Weisshauswald. There are several walking trails that go through the forest, and it's free to park and look around.
name: Wildfreigehege Weißhauswald

detail_description: Sankt Georgsbrunnen is a beautiful fountain in Trier, surrounded by a square with benches where visitors can sit and relax. It's a fine example of a fountain dedicated to St. George and the dragon, offering a peaceful spot to unwind. The area around it is filled with beer places and ice cream parlors, providing plenty of options for refreshments while enjoying the surroundings.
name: Saint George's Fountain

detail_description: The amphitheater located just outside the city center is a fascinating historical site. Built around 1,700 years ago, it once hosted thrilling battles for spectators. Although only the structure remains today, its enduring presence still captivates the imagination of visitors.
name: Amphitheater

detail_description: Karl-Marx-Haus is a museum located in Trier, the birthplace of Karl Marx. The philosopher's influence on economics, sociology, and journalism is evident in the exhibits that detail his life and work. As the founder of the labor movement, his impact on the economy is also explored. Visitors can gain insight into Marx's legacy by exploring this transformed house where he was born. The museum offers an opportunity to delve into the life and times of this influential figure.
name: Karl-Marx-Haus

detail_description: Zur Steipe is a charming café located in the Spielzeugmuseum, offering a great breakfast selection and reasonable prices. The café features a terrace with views of the Hauptmarkt, making it an ideal spot to enjoy coffee and cake.
name: Zur Steipe

detail_description: Zurlaubener Ufer is a picturesque riverside promenade located in Trier, Germany. It offers a charming blend of historic architecture, scenic views of the Moselle River, and a lively atmosphere with numerous cafes and restaurants. Visitors can take leisurely strolls along the waterfront, enjoy al fresco dining with river views, or simply relax and soak in the tranquil ambiance.
name: Zurlaubener Ufer

excerpt: Airy, light-filled museum in a former prison featuring ecclesiastical art, sculpture & objects.
detail_description: Trier Cathedral Museum, housed in a former prison, is a bright and airy space showcasing ecclesiastical art, sculptures, and various objects. While it may not be as popular as other attractions in Trier, this museum offers rich rewards to those who visit. The cathedral itself has a long history serving as the seat of the Archbishop of Trier for centuries. The museum also conducts research on the cathedral's late antique predecessor buildings, shedding light on its architectural evolution and historical significance.
name: Trier Cathedral Museum

excerpt: Mall with around 70 outlets on 3 levels including global brands & cuisine, plus regular exhibitions.
detail_description: Trier Galerie is a spacious shopping center located on three floors, offering a wide range of stores and eateries, including renowned international brands and diverse cuisines. In addition to its impressive collection of around 70 outlets, the mall regularly hosts exhibitions for visitors to enjoy. Its convenient location between the picturesque Hunsruck hills and Trier makes it an ideal choice for those who wish to experience the lively atmosphere of a city during the day but prefer staying away from its urban core.
name: Trier Galerie

detail_description: In Trier, Germany, stands the Karl-Marx-Denkmal, a 5.5-meter-high bronze statue of the renowned philosopher Karl Marx. Unveiled in May 2018 to commemorate his 200th birthday, this imposing statue was a gift from the People's Republic of China to Marx's birth city. Created by Chinese artist Wu Weishan, the statue depicts Marx striding forward with a book in his right hand and is placed on a pentagonal base.
name: Karl-Marx-Denkmal

excerpt: Charming central square with a market, ringed by ornate, colorfully painted medieval buildings.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Trier, Hauptmarkt is a delightful central square that captures the essence of medieval charm. Surrounded by vibrantly painted buildings and traditional half-timbered houses, this picturesque market square offers stunning views of iconic landmarks like Porta Nigra and the Cathedral. It's a perfect spot for people-watching or enjoying a leisurely meal at one of the many cafes and restaurants that line its edges. The centerpiece, a beautiful fountain adorned with statues representing cardinal virtues, adds to its allure.
name: Hauptmarkt

detail_description: Kanu SaarFari GbR, located about 30 minutes from Trier, offers kayak and canoe rentals for exploring the picturesque Saar River. With options for single or double kayaks, visitors can embark on four to eight-hour round tours through idyllic landscapes. Whether paddling through nature reserves or enjoying a leisurely family outing, guests appreciate the reasonable prices and helpful staff.
name: Kanu SaarFari
